Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Bistable Electroactive Polymers for Refreshable Braille Displays
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer Program Phase I project aims to develop a refreshable Braille display for the blind. Existing Braille technologies require complicated mechanical designs that are bulky and too expensive for personal use. A new technology based on a new smart material (bistable electroactive polymer) will be developed to enable a Braille dot array on a thin flat panel. The project will further the material development of this polymer, develop low-cost processing and patterning of Braille cells, and design the driving circuitry and control software. Researchers from the University of California at Los Angeles will collaborate on the project, leading further development of the smart material to obtain high actuation performance and durability.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be the availability of low-cost, lightweight refreshable Braille displays. The new Braille displays will significantly increase literacy in the blind population, particularly for children. Users will be able to communicate instantly with their teachers and peers through text messaging. The low fabrication cost will make the displays accessible to a larger portion of the 314 million people worldwide that suffer from vision impairment. The underlying technology can also be adapted to provide solutions for public access for the vision impaired. The projected market is on the order of hundred millions of dollars and could create hundreds of jobs. The project will also lead to better basic understanding of the new smart material and to new engineering designs for functional transducers with large commercial potential.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bistable Electroactive Polymers for Refreshable Braille Displays

This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project aims to develop a low cost multifunctional Braille display for commercialization. The target device can display one page of Braille text at a time. The text can be refreshed. The device is equipped with WiFi for internet access and a USB port for file loading and storage. It addresses a niche market need that is critically important for blind people. Current products displaying 1 or 2 lines of Braille cells cost about $5000 a line. The low function and high cost of the existing products have limited market penetration, and most of the blind population cannot afford for such devices.

With significantly reduced cost and more functionality, our product is expected to reach a large portion of the 1.3 million people in the United States who are legally blind. The new Braille devices will help to reverse the declining Braille literacy rate, particularly among blind children. School-age children will be able to access the vast volumes of educational materials through the internet and communicate readily with their teachers and peers. In addition, the graphics capabilities of the device will open up a whole new level of educational effectiveness and pleasure. Blind students will be able to read equations, which to date have been extremely difficult to teach. With improved Braille literacy, the employment rate of blind people will increase in the long run.

The new Braille display is enabled by the bistable electroactive polymer, an innovative new smart material invented at the University of California, Los Angeles. The polymer is capable of large-strain, rigid-to-rigid actuation. The tactile display panel will be constructed simply of a stack of polymer sheets, conductive coatings, and an x-y addressable driving circuitry. The Phase I of the STTR project involved transitioning of the smart material and actuator technology for evaluation for commercialization. The project examined the material formulation, processing, electrode patterning, actuator design, and miniaturization of a driving circuit. Diaphragm-type Braille dots, cells, and arrays of cells were successfully fabricated. The actuation strain and force output of the experimental devices measured in the laboratory were sufficiently high to meet the Braille requirements. Field test show that the texts (alphabets) were decipherable and tactile feel could be further improved. The project also investigated the smart materials to understand the fundamental structure-property relationships and improved the performance of the materials and actuators.
